title: What is sleep anxiety?
content: Sleep anxiety is fear or worry about going to sleep. You may be scared about not falling asleep or not being able to stay asleep. Some people also have a fear of sleep called somniphobia. Sleep disorders and mental health disorders like anxiety often go hand in hand, making it hard to fall or stay asleep.

title: Cycle of sleep anxiety and insomnia
content: If you have an anxiety disorder, you may find it hard to fall or stay asleep. If you have a sleep disorder, you might feel anxious before bed because you’re afraid you won’t get the rest you need. One condition usually makes the other worse, creating a never-ending cycle.

title: Symptoms of sleep anxiety
content: When you can’t sleep due to anxiety, you may feel overwhelmed, unable to concentrate, irritable, nervous, restless, or have a sense of doom. Physical effects before bed may include digestive problems, fast heart rate, rapid breathing, sweating, tense muscles, trembling, or even nocturnal panic attacks.

title: Sleep anxiety and health risks
content: Sleep anxiety puts you at higher risk for long-term complications such as diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, stroke, and more. Longstanding anxiety or lack of sleep can affect many aspects of your health.

title: How to overcome sleep anxiety: CBT-I
content: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) is considered first-line treatment for insomnia. It teaches you to break the link between bed and worry, and retrain your mind to see the bed as a place for sleeping. CBT-I often includes: keeping regular sleep and wake times, getting out of bed when awake, limiting total time in bed, relaxation, and mindfulness techniques.

title: Improve sleep hygiene to reduce anxiety
content: Ways to improve your sleep hygiene: avoid drinking lots of fluids before bed, do relaxing activities before bed (like meditation or soft music), avoid caffeine late in the day, go to bed and wake up at the same time every day, get out of bed if not asleep in 20 minutes, make sure your bedroom is comfortable and quiet, use your bed only for sleep and sex, stop using electronic devices at least 30 minutes before bed, and set a goal of at least seven hours of sleep nightly.

title: What to do if you can't sleep
content: If you don't fall asleep within 20 minutes, get out of bed and do something quiet and relaxing (read, listen to calm music, stretch lightly), then return to bed when sleepy. If worries keep you awake, try writing them down and scheduling a time to deal with them outside bedtime.

title: Prognosis: You can manage sleep anxiety
content: Most people can successfully manage their sleep anxiety with the right treatments, but some treatments such as CBT-I take time to be effective. Don’t stop trying if change seems slow—progress is possible.

title: What is sleep anxiety?
content: Sleep anxiety means you worry about falling asleep or staying asleep. Worrying about your sleep can make the problem worse, creating a cycle of anxiety and poor sleep. Sleep and anxiety are closely linked.

title: Symptoms of sleep anxiety
content: Common symptoms of sleep anxiety at night include restlessness, increased heart rate, light-headedness or dizziness, hot flushes, insomnia, and other problems with sleep.

title: Why is sleep so important?
content: Poor sleep makes daily life challenging and is linked to feeling depressed or lonely, irritability, and trouble concentrating. Over time, poor sleep increases risk for obesity, heart disease, and diabetes. Good sleep is important for health and wellbeing.

title: Causes of sleep problems and anxiety
content: Sleep anxiety can develop if you have a sleep disorder like insomnia or obstructive sleep apnoea. It may also result from stress, worry, or your daily routine. Using stimulants like caffeine or sugar, or alcohol to sleep, can make things worse.

title: Tips to improve sleep hygiene
content: Good sleep hygiene includes: going to bed and waking up around the same time each day (including days off); keeping your bedroom calm, quiet, comfortable, and cool; not going to bed until you feel sleepy; avoiding alcohol, nicotine, and caffeine near bedtime; and staying physically active during the day to improve both physical and mental health.

title: Other ways to reduce sleep anxiety
content: If sleep hygiene tips don’t work, try breathing exercises or progressive muscle relaxation (tense a muscle as you inhale, relax as you exhale). If you can’t sleep after 20 minutes, get out of bed and do a calm activity (not screens). Reading, writing, or keeping a sleep diary may help relax your mind.

title: When to seek help for sleep anxiety
content: If lack of sleep is affecting your quality of life, speak to your GP. They can help figure out what's causing your sleep issues and advise you on managing anxiety, including referral to a sleep clinic or support for mental health.

title: Bedtime Sleep Ritual (Step-by-step)
content: 1. Choose a regular bedtime and wake time—even on weekends. 2. Dim the lights one hour before bed. 3. Put away electronics 30-60 minutes before sleep. 4. Wash your face or take a warm shower. 5. Change into comfortable sleepwear. 6. Spend 10-20 minutes on a relaxing activity (reading, gentle stretching, listening to calm music, or journaling worries for tomorrow). 7. Lie in bed only when you feel sleepy, not before.

title: Guided Body Scan for Sleep (Script)
content: 1. Lie down comfortably. 2. Gently close your eyes. Allow your shoulders to relax. 3. Notice your breathing—in, out, in, out. 4. Bring your attention to your toes. Notice any tension; gently let it go on an exhale. 5. Move to your feet and ankles—notice and release any tension. 6. Move to your calves and knees, allowing them to soften. 7. Continue scanning: thighs, hips, back, stomach, chest, shoulders, arms, hands, neck, jaw, and finally face. At each spot, notice, relax, and let go. 8. If your mind wanders, bring it back to the feeling of your body sinking into the bed. Finish with three deep, slow breaths before easing into sleep.

title: Cognitive Reframing for Sleep Anxiety (Step-by-step)
content: When anxious thoughts about not sleeping arise: 1. Notice the thought (e.g., 'I’ll never fall asleep.'). 2. Challenge its accuracy: 'Is this always true? Have I always stayed awake all night?' 3. Remind yourself: 'Even if I don't sleep well, I can still function tomorrow.' 4. Replace the original worry with a more helpful thought: 'My body knows how to sleep. Rest is beneficial even if I don't sleep right away.' 5. Redirect focus to your breath or a calming image.

title: Digital Detox Routine Before Bed
content: 1. Set an alarm or reminder 60 minutes before sleep to begin your wind-down. 2. Put all screens (phone, TV, computer) out of reach or in another room. 3. Use dim lighting. 4. Engage in a non-digital activity: reading, meditating, drinking herbal tea, or gentle stretching. 5. Only get in bed when you feel sleepiness in your body.

title: Worry Journaling to Clear Your Mind at Night
content: If your mind is busy at bedtime: 1. Keep a notebook by your bed. 2. Before sleep, write down any worries or 'to-dos' that are on your mind. 3. Tell yourself you will revisit these in the morning. 4. Close the notebook and put it out of sight. 5. Gently shift focus to the present and relaxation.

title: Guided Visualization: Safe Sleep Sanctuary
content: 1. Get comfortable in bed and close your eyes. 2. Imagine a place where you feel completely safe and at ease: it might be a quiet beach, a warm cabin, or your childhood room. 3. Picture every detail: the colors, sounds, smells, the feeling of the sheets or sand under you. 4. Imagine yourself feeling more and more relaxed in this space with each breath. 5. If your mind wanders, gently return to your safe place. Remain here until you drift toward sleep.

title: Mindfulness for Sleep: Noticing the Present
content: 1. Sit or lie comfortably. 2. Begin to notice your breath—don't change it, just observe. 3. Notice any thoughts about the day, acknowledge them, then gently return your focus to breathing. 4. Move your awareness through your body, noticing any sensations without judgment. 5. If you catch yourself worrying, silently say 'thinking' and return to the present. 6. Allow thoughts to come and go, remaining with the inhale and exhale. Continue for a few minutes or until you feel calmer.

title: Sleep Affirmations for Anxiety
content: Try repeating one or more of these affirmations before bed: 'My mind and body know how to rest.' 'It's okay if I can't sleep right away; rest is useful.' 'I release today and trust sleep to come when it's ready.' 'I am safe to rest and can handle tomorrow.'

title: Counting Down Visualization
content: 1. Lie comfortably and close your eyes. 2. Visualize the number 100 in your mind's eye. 3. With each slow breath out, picture the next number in sequence, counting down: 100...99...98.... 4. If you lose your place, gently return to the last number you remember. Continue until your mind drifts or you fall asleep.

title: Letting Go Affirmation
content: Silently repeat: 'I let go of my thoughts; I let my body relax; I am ready to welcome deep, peaceful sleep.' Allow this to be your last conscious thought as you settle in for the night.
